channel.title: Xubuntu
channel.description: I wanted to try out a different OS, so I decided to get Xubuntu, which is a community developed project originally designed from Ubuntu. I was wondering if there are a lot of things you can't do in Linux, such as program use, etc, as opposed to Windows.

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @pitchblac23 pitchblac23
item.description:
@pitchblac23 wrote:

I’m also puzzled on the ones saying its slow… on my pen4 i had Ubuntu windows xp/7 running ill say Ubuntu ran the fastest. Thing ran so fast it made YouTube think it was playing in fast mode had to change drivers to slow it down lol. if you want a distribution that’s sorta close to a windows look i have used Lubuntu pretty easy to use still no real support for gaming or i would be using for now its win8 (|…|.). Really any distribution is pretty good on the Linux side of computing just for gaming id stick with windows for now. If your looking for more office work or just cheaper ways to get software then Linux is a very good choice with the software centers.

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:9, topic:456999”][quote author=Lin link=topic=559942.msg4089655#msg4089655 date=1346202905]
I really don’t recommend switching to Linux. My experience with Ubuntu was awful. I encountered numerous hardware issues, slowdowns, and inabilities to run software or find alternatives. It’s a pain to do a lot of things as it requires a lot of console work. Stick with Windows with a new theme unless you have a reason to switch to Linux.
[/quote]

how long ago was this? because it’s rare for linux to not be hardware compatible in the past 3 years[/quote]Maybe about 2 years ago. I had a Sapphire Radeon HD 3650 card, and initially the display was all messed up (like text was unreadable, icon images were corrupted, etc). All versions of drivers for it were messed up in some way.

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Lin:

I really don’t recommend switching to Linux. My experience with Ubuntu was awful. I encountered numerous hardware issues, slowdowns, and inabilities to run software or find alternatives. It’s a pain to do a lot of things as it requires a lot of console work. Stick with Windows with a new theme unless you have a reason to switch to Linux.

how long ago was this? because it’s rare for linux to not be hardware compatible in the past 3 years

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

I really don’t recommend switching to Linux. My experience with Ubuntu was awful. I encountered numerous hardware issues, slowdowns, and inabilities to run software or find alternatives. It’s a pain to do a lot of things as it requires a lot of console work. Stick with Windows with a new theme unless you have a reason to switch to Linux.

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:1, topic:457005”]there is something called like linuxliveusbcreator

it worked well for me you can install it via a usb upon turning on your pc

I’m sure t4 knows a better solution though :o[/quote]
I did that for my current version; I believe that it does indeed use the main hard drive to store data, but I don’t really like this distribution of Linux I have. I think I’m just going to get Ubuntu.

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Jaxus, post:5, topic:456999”][quote author=t4 link=topic=559942.msg4089609#msg4089609 date=1346200866]
distribution? i use arch. for a beginner, I’d stick with an ubuntu variant. install it to your OS disk. developing on linux is very easy, and in fact i develop exclusively on it. eclipse, jdk, python, idle, vim, apache ant, etc are all available in pretty much any distribution’s repository. installing them on ubuntu is as simple as ‘sudo apt-get install eclipse’
[/quote]
The only way I could find out how to install this one is to a flash drive or CD drive. Any help?

Also, do you know of any recommended source of terminal commands for Linux?[/quote]
uh yea, you burn a cd for copy the image to a flash drive and boot from it in order to run it and install it.

https://pangea.stanford.edu/computing/unix/shell/commands.php

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

t4:

distribution? i use arch. for a beginner, I’d stick with an ubuntu variant. install it to your OS disk. developing on linux is very easy, and in fact i develop exclusively on it. eclipse, jdk, python, idle, vim, apache ant, etc are all available in pretty much any distribution’s repository. installing them on ubuntu is as simple as ‘sudo apt-get install eclipse’

The only way I could find out how to install this one is to a flash drive or CD drive. Any help?

Also, do you know of any recommended source of terminal commands for Linux?

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

distribution? i use arch. for a beginner, I’d stick with an ubuntu variant. install it to your OS disk. developing on linux is very easy, and in fact i develop exclusively on it. eclipse, jdk, python, idle, vim, apache ant, etc are all available in pretty much any distribution’s repository. installing them on ubuntu is as simple as ‘sudo apt-get install eclipse’

Read full topic

item.title: Xubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

t4:

well, you’ll have to find alternatives to mostly all of your software. the only limit i can think of is gaming and potentially some really proprietary codecs… but uh, for the most part the transition is very easy assuming you don’t want to game.

As long as I can use an IDE and other general developer programs, I will be fine.

Also, do you have a recommendation for a certain type of Linux? This current one I’m using only allows you to store data on a USB.

Read full topic
